name: Propp Folktale Structure
description: A story structure for folktales  based on the teachings of Vladimir Propp

children.text: --- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Hero accomplishes a difficult task.
What makes the task difficult?
How does the Hero accomplish the task?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Hero marries and is rewarded or promoted by the family or community, typically ascending to a throne.
What is the Hero's reward?
How does the reward help to reinforce the Hero's transformation?
What is the Hero's new status?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Villain suffers the consequences of their actions, perhaps at the hands of the Hero, the avenged victims, or as a direct result of their own ploy.
Who punishes the Villain?
What form does the punishment take? (e.g. banishment, death, jail, or other)
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return

The Hero gains a new appearance. This may reflect aging and/or the benefits of labour and health, or it may constitute a magical remembering after a limb or digit was lost (as a part of the branding or from failing a trial). Regardless, it serves to improve their looks.
How is the Hero transformed?
Does the Hero regain something lost, or is it a result of their work?
Is it a physical transformation or a transformation of life, like granted nobility and an easier life?
Is the transformation natural or provided via magical means?
Examples:
Cinderella is transformed into a member of the nobility.
In The Frog Prince, the frog is transformed into a handsome prince.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The False Hero and/or Villain is exposed to all and sundry.
How is the False Hero exposed? Is it self-revelation, or is it at the hand of the Hero or others?
What is the reaction of the False Hero being exposed?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Hero is given due recognition – usually by means of their prior branding.
How does their branding relate to their being recognized?
What form does the public recognition take?
Who recognizes the Hero?
Examples:
Snow White gets to marry a prince.
In Puss in Boots, the cat is awarded the ogre's castle.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
A trial is proposed to the Hero – riddles, test of strength or endurance, acrobatics and other ordeals.
What is the proposed task?
Is there more than one task?
How will this task prove the Hero is who they are?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return

A False Hero presents unfounded claims or performs some other form of deceit. This may be the Villain, one of the Villain's underlings or an unrelated party. It may even be some form of future donor for the Hero, once they've faced their actions.
Who is the False Hero?
What claims do they make?
How do they attempt to deceive people into believing they are the Hero?
Examples:
Cinderella's stepsisters pretend to be her when the Prince comes calling.
In The Golden Bird, the older brothers try to kill their younger brother and steal his prizes.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Hero arrives, whether in a location along their journey or in their destination, and is unrecognized or unacknowledged.
Where does the Hero arrive?
Why are they unrecognized?
Are they forced into hiding?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return

The Hero is saved from a chase. Something may act as an obstacle to delay the pursuer, or the Hero may find or be shown a way to hide, up to and including transformation unrecognizably. The Hero's life may be saved by another.
Who or what interferes with the chase?
Is the Hero saved by another?
Is magic used to assist the Hero or something physical, like a well-timed rock slide?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Hero is pursued by some threatening adversary, who perhaps seeks to capture or eat them.
What adversary is chasing the Hero?
What is the threat to the Hero?
How does the Hero attempt to elude the new danger?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 4: Hero's Return
The Hero travels back to their home.
How does the Hero travel back home?
How long is the journey expected to take?
Examples:
Hansel and Gretel return home to their lamenting father.
Odysseus heads home to Ithaca.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence
The earlier misfortunes or issues of the story are resolved; the objects of search are distributed, spells broken, captives freed.
How is the earlier misfortune resolved?
What steps are required after the resolution? (e.g. returning stolen items, dispensing food, sharing new abilities)
Examples:
The witch burns in the oven and Gretel frees her brother, and they find a vase of treasures.
Grandmother and Little Red Riding Hood are freed after the woodcutter kills the wolf.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence
The Villain is defeated by the Hero – killed in combat, outperformed in a contest, struck when vulnerable, banished, and so on.
How does the Hero kill the Villain?
How has the Hero used what they learned, were granted, or found, to succeed?
Is the Villain killed, banished, or simply the clear loser of a contest?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence
The Hero is marked in some manner, perhaps receiving a distinctive scar or granted a cosmetic item like a ring or scarf.
What brand is bestowed upon the Hero?
Does the brand tie into the story? (e.g. it was foretold the chosen one would have this scar.)
Does the brand grant greater power, or is it symbolic?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence
The Hero and Villain meet and engage in conflict directly, either in battle or some nature of contest.
In what type of conflict do the Hero and Villain face off?
How close to death does the Hero come?
Is the brush with death physical or literal?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence

The Hero is transferred, delivered or somehow led to a vital location, perhaps related to one of the above functions such as the home of the donor or the location of the magical agent or its parts, or to the Villain.
Where is the Hero transferred?
How is the Hero transferred?
How does the location relate to the story?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence

The Hero acquires the use of a magical agent as a consequence of their good actions. This may be a directly acquired item, something located after navigating a tough environment, a good purchased or bartered with a hard-earned resource or fashioned from parts and ingredients prepared by the Hero, spontaneously summoned from another world, a magical food that is consumed, or even the earned loyalty and aid of another.
What is the magical agent acquired by the Hero?
How is the magical agent acquired? (e.g. found, offered, magically brought forth, or stolen.)
How will it aid them in their journey?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence

The Hero responds to the actions of their future donor, perhaps withstanding the rigours of a test and/or failing in some manner, freeing a captive, reconciles disputing parties or otherwise performing good services. This may also be the first time the Hero comes to understand the Villain's skills and powers, and uses them for good.
How does the Hero react?
How does the Hero come to understand the Villain's true powers?
What tests does the Hero pass / which do they fail?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 3: Donor Sequence
The Hero encounters a magical agent or helper (donor) on their path, and is tested in some manner through interrogation, combat, puzzles or more.
What form does the magical agent take? (e.g. talking animal, magical item, fairy godmother, or wizard.)
How does the Hero find the magical agent?
How is the Hero tested?
What are the rewards for success and the punishments for failure?
What is being offered to the Hero as the final reward?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 2: Story Body
The Hero leaves the home environment, this time with a sense of purpose. Here begins their adventure.
How has the Hero prepared themselves for the adventure?
Where are they heading?
How will their plan unfold en route or once they arrive?
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 2: Story Body

The Hero considers ways to resolve the issues by seeking a needed magical item, rescuing those who are captured or otherwise thwarting the Villain. This is a defining moment for the Hero, one that shapes their further actions and marks the point when they begin to fit their noble mantle.
How does the Hero create their plan to counter the Villain?
What do they need to seek or rescue?
How does the plan attempt to thwart the Villain?
Examples:
In Hansel and Gretel, Hansel offers the witch a thin bone in place of his finger.
In The Miraculous Hen, the children offer the cook gold to not kill them and cook them for dinner.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 2: Story Body
One or more of the negative factors covered previously comes to the attention of the Hero, who uncovers the deceit/perceives the lacking/learns of the villainous acts that have transpired.
What is the request or command given to the Hero?
Do they leave on their own accord, or are they commanded to go?
Is the Hero a Seeker (going to save a damsel) or a Victim-Hero (a victim that becomes Hero)?
Has the Hero been assisted in escape by anyone?
Examples:
The children are sent into the woods in Hansel and Gretel.
Little Red Riding Hood learns the fate of her Grandmother.
The children learn they are to be eaten in The Miraculous Hen.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 2: Story Body

The Villain harms a family member, including but not limited to abduction, theft, spoiling crops, plundering, banishment or expulsion of one or more Protagonists, murder, threatening a forced marriage, inflicting nightly torments and so on. Simultaneously or alternatively, a Protagonist finds they desire or require something lacking from the home environment (potion, artifact, etc.). The Villain may still be indirectly involved, perhaps fooling the family member into believing they need such an item.
Which family member has been harmed?
How has the family member been harmed?
What does the Protagonist find they require?
Where does the Protagonist need to go to acquire it?
Examples:
The Wolf hides the Grandmother in Little Red Riding Hood and then dresses as her to fool Red when she arrives.
In King Bear, the dragon kidnaps the Tsar's daughter.
In The Miraculous Hen, the gem-laying hen is ordered killed.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction

The victim is fooled or forced to concede and unwittingly or unwillingly helps the Villain, who is now free to access somewhere previously off-limits, like the privacy of the Hero's home or a treasure vault, acting without restraint in their ploy.
How did the method of deception work?
What did the Villain gain access to?
How has the Protagonist become mechanical at this point? (e.g. sleeping, in a trance, locked away, poisoned, etc.)
Examples:
The witch gives Snow White a poisoned apple.
While Little Red Riding Hood looks for flowers, the Wolf sneaks to her grandmother's house and pretends to be her.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction

The Villain attempts to deceive the victim to acquire something valuable. They press further, aiming to con the Hero and earn their trust. Sometimes the Villain makes little or no deception and instead ransoms one valuable thing for another.
What form of trickery does the Villain use? (e.g. disguises, transmogrification, charm, or manipulation.)
What is the Villain trying to take from the victim?
If trickery is not used, how does the Villain use coercion or force to get what they want?
Is magic used? If so, in what form?
Examples:
The Wolf encourages Little Red Riding Hood to pick flowers for her grandmother.
In King Bear, a chisel tells the bear to throw it in the ground and dig where it lands to find the Tsar's children.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction
The Villain succeeds at recon and gains a lead on their intended victim. A map is often involved in some level of the event.
What vital information is leaked?
Who leaks the information and how?
Was the information leaked by carelessness or by interacting with a magical object?
Examples:
The magic mirror in Snow White provides information to the Queen.
In The Miraculous Hen, the merchant's wife tells the young apprentice the precious gems come from the hen.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction

The Villain makes an effort to attain knowledge needed to fulfill their plot. Disguises are often invoked as the Villain actively probes for information, perhaps for a valuable item or to abduct someone. They may speak with a family member who innocently divulges a crucial insight. The Villain may also seek out the Hero in their reconnaissance, perhaps to gauge their strengths in response to learning of their special nature.
What is the information the Villain seeks?
Who do they approach for the information?
How does the Villain disguise themselves?
Examples:
The wolf in Little Red Riding Hood asks where she is headed.
The apprentice in The Miraculous Hen asks where the precious stones came from.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction

The prior rule is violated. Therefore, the Hero did not listen to the command or forbidding edict. Whether committed by the Hero by accident or temper, a third party or a foe, this generally leads to negative consequences. The Villain enters the story via this event, although not necessarily confronting the Hero. They may be a lurking and manipulative presence, or might act against the Hero's family in their absence.
How does the Hero break the rule?
What are the consequences of breaking the rule?
How does the Villain make their appearance?
Examples:
Goldilocks breaks into the Three Bear's house, though she knows it is wrong.
Adam and Eve eat an apple from the Tree of Knowledge.
The Grasshopper plays all summer instead of preparing for winter.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction
A forbidding edict or command is passed upon the Hero ('don't go there,' 'don't do this'). The Hero is warned against some action.
Who warns the Hero?
What is the Hero warned against doing?
Examples:
Little Red Riding Hood is told not to speak with strangers.
In the Bible, Adam and Eve are warned not to eat apples from the Tree of Knowledge.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
--- Add Your Details Above this Line ---
Phase 1: Introduction

After the Hero's initial situation is depicted, a member of their community or family leaves the security of the home environment. This may be the Hero themselves, or some other relation that the Hero must later rescue. This division of the cohesive family injects initial tension into the storyline. This may serve as the Hero's introduction, typically portraying them as an ordinary person.
Who is leaving home?
Why are they leaving home?
Where are they going?
Examples:
The Three Little Pigs leave home after coming of age (at their mother's urging).
Little Red Riding Hood leaves home to visit her grandmother.
Note: Your story may not include every beat in this plot structure.
